data.text: “Show me a person who never made a mistake, and I will show you a person who never did anything.
data.author: William Rosenberg, founder of Dunkin’ Donuts

data.text: “Ideas are commodity. Execution of them is not.
data.author: Michael Dell, CEO of Dell

data.text: “User experience is everything. It always has been, but it’s undervalued and underinvested in. If you don’t know user-centered design, study it. Hire people who know it. Obsess over it. Live and breathe it. Get your whole company on board.
data.author: Evan Williams, co-founder of Twitter

data.text: “A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity; an optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty.
data.author: Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister

data.text: “The man who does not work for the love of work but only for money is likely to neither make money nor find much fun in life.
data.author: Charles M. Schwab, American steel magnate

data.text: “Be undeniably good. No marketing effort or social media buzzword can be a substitute for that.
data.author: Anthony Volodkin, founder of Hype Machine

data.text: “Ideas are easy. Implementation is hard.
data.author: Guy Kawasaki, founder of AllTop

data.text: “You can say anything to anyone, but how you say it will determine how they will react.
data.author: John Rampton, entrepreneur and investor

data.text: “Always deliver more than expected.
data.author: Larry Page, co-founder of Google

data.text: “Assume you have 90 seconds with a new user before they decide to use your app or delete it.
data.author: Tamara Steffens, Acompli

data.text: “Even if you don’t have the perfect idea to begin with, you can likely adapt.
data.author: Victoria Ransom, co-founder of Wildfire Interactive

data.text: “Make your team feel respected, empowered and genuinely excited about the company’s mission.
data.author: Tim Westergen, founder of Pandora

data.text: “Stay self-funded as long as possible.
data.author: Garrett Camp, co-founder of Stumbleupon

data.text: “In between goals is a thing called life, that has to be lived and enjoyed.
data.author: Sid Caesar, Entertainer

data.text: “Wonder what your customer really wants? Ask. Don’t tell.
data.author: Lisa Stone, co-founder of BlogHer

data.text: “When times are bad is when the real entrepreneurs emerge.
data.author: Robert Kiyosaki, author of Rich Dad Poor Dad

data.text: “What do you need to start a business? Three simple things: know your product better than anyone, know your customer, and have a burning desire to succeed.
data.author: Dave Thomas, founder of Wendy’s

data.text: “Get big quietly, so you don’t tip off potential competitors.
data.author: Chris Dixon, co-founder of Hunch

data.text: “Don’t worry about failure; you only have to be right once.
data.author: Drew Houston, founder of Dropbox

data.text: “Your time is limited, so don’t waste it living someone else’s life. Don’t be trapped by dogma
data.author: which is living with the results of other people’s thinking. Don’t let the noise of other’s opinions drown out your own inner voice. And most important, have the courage to follow your heart and intuition. They somehow already know what you truly want to become. Everything else is secondary.”

data.text: “Don’t be cocky. Don’t be flashy. There’s always someone better than you.
data.author: Tony Hsieh, Zappos.com CEO

data.text: “Don’t take too much advice. Most people who have a lot of advice to give — with a few exceptions — generalize whatever they did. Don’t over-analyze everything. I myself have been guilty of over-thinking problems. Just build things and find out if they work.
data.author: Ben Silbermann, co-founder of Pinterest

data.text: “Openly share and talk to people about your idea. Use their lack of interest or doubt to fuel your motivation to make it happen.
data.author: Todd Garland, founder of BuySellAds

data.text: “How you climb a mountain is more important than reaching the top.
data.author: Yvon Chouinard, founder of Patagonia

data.text: “Associate yourself with people of good quality, for it is better to be alone than in bad company.
data.author: Booker T. Washington, Educator and author

data.text: “It’s fine to celebrate success but it is more important to heed the lessons of failure.
data.author: Bill Gates, co-founder of Microsoft

data.text: “It takes 20 years to build a reputation and five minutes to ruin it. If you think about that, you’ll do things differently.
data.author: Warren Buffett, Investor

data.text: “Statistics suggest that when customers complain, business owners and managers ought to get excited about it. The complaining customer represents a huge opportunity for more business.
data.author: Zig Ziglar, author and motivational speaker

data.text: “There is only one success- to be able to spend your life in your own way.
data.author: Christopher Morley, journalist

data.text: “Formal education will make you a living; self-education will make you a fortune.
data.author: Jim Rohn, author and speaker

data.text: “When everything seems to be going against you, remember that the airplane takes off against the wind, not with it.
data.author: Henry Ford, founder of Ford Motor Company

data.text: “Rarely have I seen a situation where doing less than the other guy is a good strategy.
data.author: Jimmy Spithill, Australian yachtsman

data.text: “You miss 100 percent of the shots you don’t take.
data.author: Wayne Gretzky, NHL Hall of Famer

data.text: “The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.
data.author: Chinese proverb

data.text: “The secret to successful hiring is this: look for the people who want to change the world.
data.author: Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce

data.text: “Twenty years author now, you will be more disappointed by the things that you didn’t do than by the ones you did do, so throw off the bowlines, sail away author safe harbor, catch the trade winds in your sails. Explore, Dream, Discover.
data.author: Mark Twain, author

data.text: “If you’ve got an idea, start today. There’s no better time than now to get going. That doesn’t mean quit your job and jump into your idea 100% author day one, but there’s always small progress that can be made to start the movement.
data.author: Kevin Systrom, co-founder of Instagram

data.text: “It’s almost always harder to raise capital than you thought it would be, and it always takes longer. So plan for that.
data.author: Richard Harroch, Venture Capitalist

data.text: “For all of the most important things, the timing always sucks. Waiting for a good time to quit your job? The stars will never align and the traffic lights of life will never all be green at the same time. The universe doesn’t conspire against you, but it doesn’t go out of its way to line up the pins either. Conditions are never perfect. “Someday is a disease that will take your dreams to the grave with you. Pro and con lists are just as bad. If it’s important to you and you want to do it “eventually, just do it and correct course along the way.
data.author: Timothy Ferriss, author of The 4-Hour Work Week

data.text: “I don’t have big ideas. I sometimes have small ideas, which seem to work out.
data.author: Matt Mullenweg, founder of Automattic

data.text: “Fail often so you can succeed sooner.
data.author: Tom Kelley, Ideo partner

data.text: “When you cease to dream you cease to live.
data.author: Malcolm Forbes, chairman and editor in chief of Forbes Magazine

data.text: “Whatever the mind can conceive and believe, the mind can achieve.
data.author: Dr. Napoleon Hill, author of Think and Grow Rich

data.text: “Running a start-up is like eating glass. You just start to like the taste of your own blood.
data.author: Sean Parker, co-founder of Napster

data.text: “My number one piece of advice is: you should learn how to program.
data.author: Mark Zuckerberg, founder of Facebook

data.text: “The way to get started is to quit talking and begin doing.
data.author: Walt Disney, co-founder of the Walt Disney Company

data.text: “The pace of change for entrepreneurs is rapidly accelerating, and the cost and risk of launching a new business and getting off the ground is just amazing. The ability to gain user feedback really quickly and adapt to what your consumers want is totally different with the web as it is now. But finding a new market, helping people and taking that original idea and turning it into a business is really exciting right now.
data.author: Matt Mickiewicz, co-founder of 99 Designs

data.text: “Building and hanging on to an audience is the biggest role of social media.
data.author: Matthew Inman, The Oatmeal

data.text: “Every feature has some maintenance cost, and having fewer features lets us focus on the ones we care about and make sure they work very well.
data.author: David Karp, founder of Tumblr

data.text: “A poorly implemented feature hurts more than not having it at all.
data.author: Noah Everett, founder of Twitpic

data.text: “This defines entrepreneur and entrepreneurship
data.author: the entrepreneur always searches for change, responds to it, and exploits it as an opportunity.”― Peter F. Drucker, educator and author

data.text: “You don’t learn to walk by following rules. You learn by doing and falling over.
data.author: Richard Branson, founder of Virgin Group

data.text: “The fastest way to change yourself is to hang out with people who are already the way you want to be.
data.author: Reid Hoffman, co-founder of Linkedin

data.text: “Risk more than others think is safe. Dream more than others think is practical.
data.author: Howard Schultz, CEO of Starbucks

data.text: “You shouldn’t focus on why you can’t do something, which is what most people do. You should focus on why perhaps you can, and be one of the exceptions.
data.author: Steve Case, co-founder of AOL

data.text: “The critical ingredient is getting off your butt and doing something. It’s as simple as that. A lot of people have ideas, but there are few who decide to do something about them now. Not tomorrow. Not next week. But today. The true entrepreneur is a doer not a dreamer.
data.author: Nolan Bushnell, founder of Atari

data.text: “If you cannot do great things, do small things in a great way.
data.author: Napoleon Hill, author

data.text: “Success is not what you have, but who you are.
data.author: Bo Bennet, author and entreprenuer

data.text: “One of the huge mistakes people make is that they try to force an interest on themselves. You don’t choose your passions; your passions choose you.
data.author: Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon.com

data.text: “Lots of companies don’t succeed over time. What do they fundamentally do wrong? They usually miss the future.
data.author: Larry Page, CEO of Google

data.text: “It takes humility to realize that we don’t know everything, not to rest on our laurels and know that we must keep learning and observing. If we don’t, we can be sure some startup will be there to take our place.
data.author: Cher Wang, CEO of HTC

data.text: “There’s an entrepreneur right now, scared to death, making excuses, saying, ‘It’s not the right time just yet.’ There’s no such thing as a good time. Get out of your garage and go take a chance, and start your business.
data.author: Kevin Plank, CEO of Under Armour

data.text: “Be really picky with your hiring, and hire the absolute best people you possibly can. People are the most important component of almost every business, and attracting the best talent possible is going to make a huge difference.
data.author: Peter Berg, founder of October Three

data.text: “Worry about being better; bigger will take care of itself. Think one customer at a time and take care of each one the best way you can.
data.author: Gary Comer, founder of Land’s End

data.text: “You have a viable business only if your product is either better or cheaper than the alternatives. If it’s not one or the other, you might make some money at first, but it’s not a sustainable business.
data.author: Jim Koch, founder of Boston Beer Co.

data.text: “Every time I took these bigger risks, the opportunity for a bigger payout was always there.
data.author: Casey Neistat, filmmaker

data.text: “If you can do something to get somebody excited — not everybody — but if you can be the best for somebody, then you can win.
data.author: Ron Shaich, founder and CEO of Panera Bread

data.text: “Would you like me to give you a formula for success? It’s quite simple, really: Double your rate of failure. You are thinking of failure as the enemy of success. But it isn’t at all. You can be discouraged by failure or you can learn author it, so go ahead and make mistakes. Make all you can. Because remember that’s where you will find success.
data.author: Thomas J. Watson, businessman

data.text: “People who succeed have momentum. The more they succeed, the more they want to succeed, and the more they find a way to succeed. Similarly, when someone is failing, the tendency is to get on a downward spiral that can even become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
data.author: Tony Robbins, motivational speaker

data.text: “The only limit to our realization of tomorrow will be our doubts of today.
data.author: Franklin D. Roosevelt

data.text: “The successful warrior is the average man, with laser-like focus.
data.author: Bruce Lee, actor and martial arts instructor

data.text: “Fall seven times and stand up eight.
data.author: Japanese proverb

data.text: “The successful man is the one who finds out what is the matter with his business before his competitors do.
data.author: Roy L. Smith, animator and film director

data.text: “There’s no shortage of remarkable ideas, what’s missing is the will to execute them.
data.author: Seth Godin, author and speaker

data.text: “Keep on going, and the chances are that you will stumble on something, perhaps when you are least expecting it. I never heard of anyone ever stumbling on something sitting down.
data.author: Charles F. Kettering, inventor

data.text: “A successful man is one who can lay a firm foundation with the bricks others have thrown at him.
data.author: David Brinkley, newscaster

data.text: “Everyone is a genius. But if you judge a fish by its ability to climb a tree, it will spend its whole life believing it is stupid.
data.author: Albert Einstein, Theoretical Physicist

data.text: “Success in business requires training and discipline and hard work. But if you’re not frightened by these things, the opportunities are just as great today as they ever were.
data.author: David Rockefeller, American banker

data.text: “It is never too late to be what you might have been.
data.author: George Eliot, journalist and novelist

data.text: “I am not a product of my circumstances. I am a product of my decisions.
data.author: Stephen Covey, author and businessman

data.text: “There is only one way to avoid criticism: Do nothing, say nothing, and be nothing.
data.author: Aristotle, Greek philosopher

data.text: “Build your own dreams, or someone else will hire you to build theirs.
data.author: Farrah Gray, investor and motivational speaker

data.text: “You may be disappointed if you fail, but you are doomed if you don’t try.
data.author: Beverly Sills, operatic soprano
